definition: Yang Xiong (53 BC-18 AD), scholar, poet and lexicographer, author of the first Chinese dialect dictionary 方言[Fang1 yan2]
abbr. for 揚州|扬州[Yang2 zhou1]/surname Yang
to raise/to hoist/the action of tossing or winnowing/scattering (in the wind)/to flutter/to propagate
male/staminate/grand/imposing/powerful/mighty/person or state having great power and influence

sentences.english: Starting with researches of Dialect itself, the linguistic thinking of Yangxiong is discussed.
sentences.chinese: 從《方言》本身的研究入手，探討了揚雄的語言思想。

sentences.english: Yang Xiong should not be neglected when the track of self-consciousness of literature is viewed.
sentences.chinese: 當我們審視文學自覺的軌跡之時，不應忽視揚雄。

definition: Mr Gongyang's Annals or commentary on 春秋[Chun1 qiu1], early history, probably written by multiple authors during Han dynasty, same as 公羊春秋[Gong1 yang2 Chun1 qiu1]
The School Sayings of Confucius (abbr. for 孔子家語|孔子家语[Kong3 zi3 Jia1 yu3])
Yi Zhuan, commentary on the "Book of Changes" or "I Ching" 易經|易经[Yi4 jing1]
to check and correct
Liu Xiang (77-6 BC), Han Dynasty scholar and author
Yang Zhu (c. 440-360 BC), Chinese philosopher advocating ethical egoism
"Strategies of the Warring States", chronicle of the Warring States Period (475-220 BC), possibly written by Su Qin 蘇秦|苏秦[Su1 Qin2]
commentary and subcommentary (of a book)
the Hundred Schools of Thought, the various schools of thought and their exponents during the Spring and Autumn and Warring States Periods (770-220 BC)
Zheng Xuan (127-200), late Han scholar
Kong Yingda (574-648), Confucian scholar
On learning, classic book by Confucian philosopher Xun Zi 荀子 (c. 310-237 BC)
sound and meaning
School of Mind/Neo-Confucian Idealistic School (from Song to mid-Qing times, c. 1000-1750, typified by the teachings of Wang Yangming 王陽明|王阳明[Wang2 Yang2 ming2])
Sima Qian (145-86 BC), Han Dynasty historian, author of Records of the Grand Historian 史記|史记[Shi3 ji4], known as the father of Chinese historiography
Classic of Rites (same as 禮記|礼记[Li3 ji4])
